author: Worried123
title: We are back at square one
body: In late April, myself and my former partner's family presented them at QEUH A&E due to extreme paranoia, hallucinations, they are in a psychotic state, danger to themselves and others. Medics sedated him, they remained in resus most of the night, were briefly transferred to ARU3 where I voiced concerns he would abscond. Then transferred to 5C and infact absconded. I found them in A&E extremely disturbed, I am thankful to the Dr who completed an EDC they were detained under mental health act. The following day they were assessed by psychiatry who deemed them no longer in an acute psychosis and discharged them. I really don't know how they could assess this clinical outcome. My former partner was calling me hallucinating and in delusional state and I am not of the same clinical opinion of psychiatrist. He was discharged and over the weekend remains displaying severe psychosis symptoms. Last night he agreed to return to hospital for his safety and public safety. We arrived at QEUH carpark and he absconded. I sought assistance from a family member and we located him. We had no option to contact the police for his welfare, as he is a danger to himself and others due to mental health , i can't fault the police, they accompanied him to a&e where upon assessment triage had to be physically restrained , he was taken to leverndale for assessment. I'm guessing they again attributed his behaviour to drug abuse, but this is not the case whatsoever. He is extremely mentally ill and no one is listening within healthcare services. Within an hour he was discharged from leverndale. To put it bluntly he needs urgent help and I'm at the stage now what does he need to do to get help for his own safety and others safety? Absolutely ashamed of GGC mental health services, a service which I defended when I often heard feedback like this. I have seen it for myself now. Absolutely no words can fathom this experience. We are back at square one with an extremely acutely ill psychotic patient who cannot be safely managed in the community.

readBy.name: Yorkshire & Humber Patient Safety Research Collaboration
Office of Johann Lamont, MSP for Glasgow Pollok

author: Movilla
title: Covid vaccine
body: Had an appointment at SSE for first dose. V well organised and guided through every step of the way. From giving medical information right through to the wonderful nurse, Amy, we were well looked after and afterwards when we were obs for 15 mins. Thanks one and all!

readBy.name: South Eastern Health and Social Care Trust

author: woodpeckerje97
title: Replace the implant
body: I feel very well. My nurse Anna is absolutely a professional nurse. Very gentle and responsive.

author: correspondencekq56
title: Lovely lovely staff
body: Just wanted to take the opportunity to praise the nurses and doctor that I encounterd today and in the past. Marjory (I think is her name) is always extreamly friendly and kind and makes u feel at ease. Dr Nandy is always friendly and polite and explains everything to you.

author: mikeeh48
title: Coil check
body: I spoke with a lovely women named Caroline on the phone and we managed to get an appointment that was great timing then I went to the appointment and both ladies were lovely they were Caroline and unfortunately I can’t remember the name of the other women but they made me feel very comfortable and made and awkward appointment much more manageable

author: funnyhr77
title: Clinical miscommunications
body: I've had similar bad experiences to my friends when Lakeside healthcare said they informed NHS 111 they administed the COVID-19 Vaccine, but never received the injection, asked NHS 111 and confirmed Lakeside healthcare hasn't registered had the Covid-19 Vaccine, which we haven't. This clinical miscommunications is dangerous and is delaying vulnerable patients, from receiving the Covid-19 Vaccine at the right time, but receiving serious mix ups and confusing us.

author: Wobwe89
title: Covid vaccine mess up?
body:
In January my whole family caught covid, a week before we caught it my dad who was 85 years old at the time had a letter from nhs saying he'd got to go to Birmingham for vaccine. I phoned blakenall family practice and after 47 calls!!!! We finally got through.  
The secretary told us we shouldn't have had that letter and book dad for jab at oak park centre. A week after vaccine my dad, 2 sisters, mom, myself, my wife and son all caught covid. Dads chest wasnt very good and docs refused to come and see him and just sent antibiotics.  
Couple of weeks later dad was taken to hospital and passed away.  
When phoning about seeing about my disabled sister having jab we was told that she'd been missed and that the secretary would book her on for vaccine at oak park. When I took my sister we was told that her name wasnt down but would give her it anyway as theres always spare.  
Covid has made my asthma worse and after finally speaking to a doctor because 2 of my online consultations wasn't answered they prescribed me a stronger combination steroid inhaler which can make me more prone to catching infections and is organizing chest xrays.  
They told me to ask reception about trying to get a vaccine as soon as possible. So I asked when I went to get my prescription and the receptionist was very snappy and said no you must wait your turn. I even explained that my job involves coming into contact with public facing staff at approximately 20 different high risk locations a day but this staff member just didn't want to know.  
Now I have recently found out 3 of my relations all younger than me, 2 have very mild asthma symptoms using only blue inhalers, other relation has no health problems, none of them have had covid but all 3 have had first vaccines and all are registered at same practice. How is this organised and how long has it been that a receptionist has a right to pick and choose who gets vaccine. Absolutely disgusting and I'm now worried that I'm going to be missed just like my sister and dont think I could get through another bout of covid.

author: hahajopo1
title: Poor communication and attitude
body:
I had a cough just before Christmas (not Covid related) which lasted well over 6 weeks and the antibiotics did not work so after a telephone consult the doctor told me to go to the hospital for an x-ray and informed me I would not need to book an appointment and just turn up (which i did think was odd) so of course I assume the doctors must of booked an appointment for me, turn up at hospital no appointment available but luckily the staff at the hospital were really nice and still took me for a x-ray and tell me the results will be with my surgery in a few days.  
4 weeks pass and I don't hear anything, I ring the surgery to see where my results are during the day and the person at reception cannot give me my results as its not the right time in the day (lol) but I could call back after work (4pm) to get my results then, so I ring again (after being put on hold for about 40mins) and get told by another person on reception that the first person should not of told me that and I would have to ring back in the morning and also they might not even have my results yet. It wasn't until I actually got very angry with the second person, who in my opinion was very rude to me, that they gave me my results (which they did have after all) which were fine in the end.  
I was just very angry that a) they did not book me an appointment at the hospital or at least tell me I would have to it and b) have my results for since the x-ray and basically it seemed like the staff on reception couldn't be bothered to go and get them.  
I've been mucked about and treated awfully so many times with this surgery it's not even funny, including an incident where I was having a smear test done and another nurse just barged in without even knocking and opening the door really wide so anyone walking past at the time could see into the room  
I've left reviews about this place before but I've finally moved and will be signing up to a new surgery.

author: Woman on the Spectrum
title: Feeling let down
body:
I had my assessment in March after being referred by my GP. GP was great, listened and agreed to make referral.  
Scottish Autism have really let me down. The assessors on the panel were very old fashioned in their thinking of Autism presentations, being told from one of the panel they couldn't see it (i.e. my Autism?!) And because I had no (obvious) issues in childhood and I could communicate with the panel, therefore I can't be Autistic. I was laughed at for making notes, even though I need notes to remind me of what I wish to say, to help me. I was told to stop making notes and that it's not Autism, just poor self-esteem. Told to go home and chill out. Also told that I don't want this diagnosis anyway, as it would stay with me the rest of my life.  
If this practice is deemed acceptable, then I fear for all the other women who have been let down by their assessors. My health (mental and physical) has taken a turn for the worst since my assessment, due to the sheer frustration of being told I am not what I know myself to be. The assessors seem to think that a diagnosis is a bad/negative thing, when in actual fact, it would have helped me in understanding myself better and I could free myself from the guilt I've carried for the issues I've faced in the past.  
I put in a complaint, and of course, the usual... they will learn from my experience! If that's the case, then why are there still women complaining about the very same things?  
I didn't meet the diagnostic criteria... maybe then the diagnostic criteria needs looked at and altered to fit with the 21st century and the ever-changing medical field to include traits in women, as we all know they can be vastly different from the usual male presentations.  
Deeply disappointed, lost, and will be complaining to the NHS about the service. Something needs done to change this practice/criteria! Too many women being told they are not Autistic when we know different, after all, I've experienced it my entire life!  
And, unfortunately, as I've read on here AND elsewhere, sadly, I'm not the only one let down by the diagnostic criteria that is made for boys with typical indicators of male autism. The assessors should be aware that it is a spectrum, and that not every person will be 'obviously Autistic'?  
Shocking and a real shame that I know I'm not the only one!

readBy.name: St. Andrews University ScotGEM Medical Students
South Lanarkshire Health and Social Care Forum

author: Bluebells13
title: Dad with Alzheimer’s
body: My father had been admitted to crosshouse on Monday. Care in A and E was great. He has now been moved to the wards and has had no personal care. He is still in the same clothes he wore when admitted to hospital. Hospital has been advised my dad requires   assistance but nothing has been done. Distressed to hear he has also been put in an adult nappy when at home this is not required. During this tough times families rely on the care of the staff and in particular families of Alzheimer’s patients as we cannot communicate with our loved ones. Very disappointed that my dad has been left in this way.

author: gccgirl9
authorRole: a staff member posting for a carer/relative
title: Gran's Stroke
body:
My gran suffered a stroke in July 2020 and was taken to the Vic where she was in AU1 for just over a day and then moved to ward 42. At this time visiting was allowed for 1 hour per day for one visitor. I thought her and the family's experience was a mixed one.  
Whilst in AU1 there was very little communication with the family regarding her condition - When I called asking about my gran her NOK details were incorrect - a name no-one in my family has ever heard of. However the nurse I spoke with was very helpful on the phone and provided reassurance regarding my gran.  
When she was moved to ward 42 we were not informed when this happened. The care she received in the ward was very good, especially by the physios. As I was my grans designated visitor I saw the progression in my grans mobility and her white board behind her bed was continually updated with her new mobility levels. The nurses were helpful regarding my grans discharge planning and kept me informed appropriately. They were very understanding and allowed me to take my gran down to the front door for fresh air when I visited which I believe increased my grans mood whilst in the hospital.  
The only annoying thing regarding the 1 hour visiting slot was that there were a few occasions when myself ( and other relatives) were waiting anywhere between 5 and 20 minutes before being allowed entry onto the ward. I understand the staff are busy during this time but it was frustrating when under a one hour time slot and as I work in a hospital based my visiting times off my shift start/end times.

author: Stiffy
title: Lack of understanding
body: After several weeks in Monklands hospital ( and a day in Hairmyres) for investigation of breathlessness -, it was discovered that my aortic stenosis was worse and that I also had some heart artery damage.   I have undergone X-ray, MRI, echocardiogram, angiogram, respiratory testing, blood testing, urine testing. I was referred to the Golden Jubilee with the prospect of surgical intervention, outlined by Monklands and by Golden Jubilee. I have been carefully isolating myself for six weeks to ensure I caught no infection ( I am Covid vaccinated and dental checked)   it came as a complete shock today to find that the surgery will not go ahead as anticipated and I am being returned to the care of the consultants at Monklands hospital with absolutely no idea as to when I will be seen. I am totally stressed out, worried constantly about my health and feel as if I am being labelled as a Munchausen sufferer, when in fact I am living my days in fear. I cannot understand all the delays, talks at cross purposes, promises which do not materialise, when I have done everything to keep myself in best health under the circumstances. I am alone and feel unwanted by the medical profession.

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2021)

author: VeryDisappointed
title: Cannot get through on the phone
body:
It seems this hospital has no human receptionists answering telephones, but just uses an answerphone mailbox which no one checks! I have tried calling the Gynaecology Outpatients department numerous times to rebook an appointment after I was sent a letter confirming an appointment for the next day (needless to say I received the latter too late and missed the appointment).  
Alas, no one ever answers the phone and when I do leave my name, date of birth and email address and landline number, and the answerphone message says the mailbox is manned and people are called back, I have never once been contacted by a staff member. Today I contacted the PALS team in the hope I could lodge a complaint, but not even that phone number elicits a pick up from someone.  
Imagine if you lost a relative in this hospital, and were bereaved, and needed to call PALS for an explanation about their death, only to be put through to an answerphone? Well, I expect that is the experience of the poor people who contact this hospital. Seeing as I cannot get through to anyone to make a complaint, I will write this, sending my comments into the ether in the hope that some responsible member of the medical establishment might see this.  
As I notice other people have had similar problems, going back two years or more, it is disappointing to know that this hospital still has not got its act together. I feel this is totally chaotic.

author: Concerned of Haringey
title: Urgent MH care - lack of.
body:
My ex neighbour has schizophrenia and has been housed miles away in supported accommodation. Last night he showed up on our doorstep in Haringey in a disheveled,hungry and confused state. He has not had his Depo injection for 3 months. He had left the accommodation 3 months ago (unhappy there; he owes them money) and has been living rough or sofa surfing. We suspect he has been selling sex. He was covered in bruises and scratches. He is well known to dealers in this area and they have exploited him over the years. He had been with them last night. We bathed him.  
I emailed homeless team. They can see him in 3 days.  
I phoned Mental Health Crisis Team who refused to come and see him. They acted rude, unprofessional and unhelpful. The first person I spoke to refused to give me their name.  
My adult daughter and I both have depression and anxiety. I have a diagnosis of PTSD. The ex neighbour, whilst really sweet, has a history of violence. There was no way I could keep him overnight but I couldn't throw him out. MH Crisis Team did not care that they were leaving a potentially violent male with 2 vulnerable women.  
I phoned an ambulance and was told not to feed him because he needed his injection and food would affect it. He was starving.  
After an hour the paramedics arrived. They said we could give him what we liked - very rude and dismissive.  
They talked to him and said that they had to make enquiries. After 20 minutes they came and "talked" to him. By that I mean towered over him and spoke aggressively and patronisingly about how he had made himself homeless; how he owed the housing association money ; how it was his fault he hadn't had his injection. I tried to explain that it was difficult for someone with his problems to do those things. They were adamant they would not take him to hospital and that he had to make his own way to his accommodation 40 miles away , at 10p.m. They were also unconcerned about leaving him with 2 vulnerable women. My anxiety was kicking in and I told them to leave.  
My daughter spoke to the supported accommodation and they agreed to have him back today. We found a local relative who agreed to let him sleep on his sofa for £20, pizza and snacks.  
I am going to collect him now, by taxi, to take him to the supported accommodation. The round trip will cost me around £70. I am on Universal Credit.  
I am disgusted at the lack of support for this vulnerable man and for my family.

readBy.name: Barnet, Enfield and Haringey Mental Health NHS Trust x
Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2021)

author: Doodledame
title: A recent hospital stay in Queen Alexandra's Hospital Portsmouth
body:
I was blue lighted into hospital one day mid April on the verge of an adrenal crisis due to being unwell. Both the paramedics & A&E doctor were really good, the A&E doctor had worked with a leading expert on Adrenal Insufficiency so she knew the protocol to follow.  
Unfortunately the doctors & nurses on the ward knew very little about Adrenal Insufficiency as it is a rare condition. It is a life threatening condition which requires steroids being given on time, they had no understanding of this. I didn't feel safe & had to keep a close eye on what they were prescribing for me & checking that they were giving me the right medication. I'm a expert patient of my condition however that wasn't taken into account. Their Endocrine department should have been alerted that I was an inpatient, & to advise the doctors of the correct treatment - I never saw an Endo at any time.  
Although it is a rare condition they should have researched it to find out more & how it affected me especially as I had sepsis form pneumonia.  
A protocol needs to be in place for other patients with either Addison's Disease or Adrenal Insufficiency as I am aware of at least 6 others in the area who would come under the care of QA.

author: Anonymous ghost
title: Staff that I am concerned
body: I respect nurses so much but my care from the ward 11E team has been a joke. Poor communication and staff attitude. I tell them something they forget and also it’s very concerning as COVID time they don’t show they care about risk or cleaning. It’s sad this was meant to be just a feedback but there are many elderly vulnerable patients which I am 100% sure they have no clue. If this is being done to me, I'm sure some nurses must be doing to many others.

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2022)

author: Karsr88
title: Nhs Scotland Dermatology referral
body:
6 months ago I called my GP due to a scab on my arm that wasn’t healing, I had the scab at that point for a few months. GP carried out video call and advised me it looked like a wart, no follow up or further discussion.  
I happened to attend the surgery 2 weeks later regarding another matter and the I showed another GP my scab and at which point GP took a picture and sent it to dermatology. I received a letter 2 days later from dermatology saying I had been referred but due to the pandemic not sure when I will be seen. This at the beginning of October 2020, no communication/tests etc for 5 months, I chased my referral and dermatology appointment with my GP who said they didn’t have any details.  
I then received a call a few weeks later asking me to go for medical photography appointment, this was 5 months after referral, I chased the result of the medical photography twice in 2 weeks, no one had looked at them yet? I called a 3rd time to be told I need to be seen by a dermatologist? Appointment made for 3 weeks time April 2021 will be my first appointment. Since the appointment was made I have since found an enlarged superclavacular lymph node, the scab is still present on my arm and hasn’t healed at all, I am genuinely concerned at the length of time this has taken.

readBy.name: MASScot- Melanoma Action and Support Scotland

author: browsermx77
title: Lack of support for the housebound
body: I have had 1st needle at st dunstans and recieved message to go to Whistons Health Centre for 2nd I can only get to local places I am told st dunstans have stopped doing it I have mobility problems and very agitated in a car or taxi there should be a arrangement for disabled people to have a home visit to get the needle I have a very bad hip wich has dislocated 5 times in last year I am fearful of it dislocating whist I am out in taxi I only have to move wrong way and its come out also have a bad knee on opposite leg please help me thank you

readBy.name: St Helens and Knowsley Hospitals NHS Trust

author: Aquarius12
title: Trying to get medical help for my son after an accident
body:
My son fell off a neighbour's scooter and landed on his face. His nose was bleeding but there was blood everywhere and it was difficult to ascertain where it was coming from as his teeth and mouth were covered in blood too. I first phoned NHS24 on 111, and after a long automated Covid message I was told to hang up now and contact my GP  
I noted that the surgery would still be open as it was 5.40pm and still within opening hours. I spoke to someone at my GPs who told me there was nothing she could do and she said she didn't know why I got that message as I really needed to phone 111 as it would be minor injuries I needed. I asked her several times if there was anyone there who could see my son and she said no but she told me I could ring minor injuries directly.  
My son was still very distressed but fortunately my husband had arrived home, it was now 5.50pm. Having broken my ankle 6wks previously, my mobility in the moonboot was hindered. I phoned minor injuries at Stirling and spoke to someone who asked if I had spoken to someone at NHS 24, I explained what had happened. He said I would need to call back 111 in order to be triaged online and then probably booked in to come to Stirling.  
The time was now 5.55pm. My son was being reassured and beginning to calm and his nosebleed had stopped. We were also now reassured that there was no bleeding from his mouth, teeth or anywhere else. (both work first aiders) Having telephoned 111 again, listened to the automated Covid conversation again I was then triaged and told to take my son to A&E within the next hour. We went straight there following the instructions. We arrived and it was very busy, the nurse at the 1st reception told me that someone would see my son and determine whether he would have to be checked over by a doctor or if we could go instead to Urgent Care as they were very busy and we might be seen sooner.  
After an hour or so we saw a member of staff who gave our son a check over, I asked if it would be possible to go to Urgent Care and she said, she would prefer him to get checked over by the doctor as he was looking a bit peaky. She did however suggest that if we could get him looking more perky within the hour then it would be possible. I relayed this to my husband, and we got to work reassuring and distracting, as we were sure that he was just a little scared, but had not, in our limited knowledge, shown any of the obvious worries associated with a bash to the head. No sickness, no dizziness, no confusion etc  
At 8pm, the A&E dept was still very busy, with injured people arriving all the time, and the staff were very obviously doing their best but the board said waiting time was 6hrs. With a now, very hungry son and husband I approached the person we saw earlier to ask if my son could now go to Urgent Care as he seemed much better within himself. I was then told, 'Urgent Care have no appointments and I should probably have said that earlier"  
We waited another hour (9pm) and I approached the 1st reception to ask if it was ok if we took my son home as he was feeling well, but hungry and tired. I said I was sensible and prepared to keep an eye on him and if I had any concerns then I would bring him back straight away. She said there were 4 more people in front of him but she had no idea how long this would take. She checked with the consultant and that was fine to go.  
At 9pm we left for home. This morning an A&E doctor telephoned me to ask after our son as there were no notes detailing what had happened to him and at first I thought I was going to get told off for taking him home. I was reassured with an apology for the long wait, and delighted that he suggested we come back to check there was no gravel in his face today. We did this and after an hour was delighted that an A&E doctor was able to clean him up and treat his injuries. We left with some medicine and a bundle of reassurance.  
My story is written to ask for some consideration to a more joined up service approach. The mixed and confusing messages given by the GP receptionist and indeed the recorded message at NHS24. At that anxious time, all a parent is looking for is direction to the best medical attention as soon and as quickly as possible, not to be passed from pillar to post with each department saying, ' No I'm not het for this one' I am sure it is more complex than this, but it would be good if the services could work together to make better outcomes. Thanks again to the staff at Forth Valley for their attention in what are stretched and difficult times.

author: Rhona D
title: X-ray department
body: My sister mistakenly went to the wrong hospital for a scan when we should have been at Wishaw. They could not accommodate us so we called Wishaw X-Ray. They advised that we make our way to Wishaw. On getting there, some considerable time after our scheduled appointment, my sister was taken quickly and the nurses and reception staff were first class. Thank you for making a rotten experience so much better. Wishaw site and the all over culture that you feel when you walk into the building is so welcoming and reassuring.

readBy.name: North Lanarkshire Health & Social Care Partnership

author: KaE2021
title: Mental health
body: Support from the single point of access in Sheffield for mental health and the home treatment team has seemed beyond incompetent. My wife has been deteriorating for weeks and we have found both teams beyond useless. The only thing that worked was an admission to the du at the longley centre. On her last visit she was given a care plan quote clearly stating that she should be referred back there if in crisis. The spa team are refusing to do this and she has gone from not harming herself for 12 years to harming herself multiple times a day

readBy.name: Sheffield Health and Social Care NHS Foundation Trust

author: RayFaeTroon
title: Suspected UTI
body:
After four days of intermittent discomfort, initially 3 days just 6 hours up in total, I had to call 111  
I think it was Lauren the call handler, Jenny the nurse? I drove to Crosshouse, the drive distracted my focus on the issue. Inwas seen quite quickly by Triage, at first it looked like a referral to GP, it soon changed when I explained the background 2 years ago. It was not long before Dr Sam looked at me, very clear explanation, with humour too. I had the urine test, and bladder scan, and at least no catheter! Look back for the lowdown on that one.  
So thank you all, Crosshouse ED Dr Sam on my Baxter Easter Honours list for 2022, as it's too late to buy extra this year. It would be nice to include the call handlers and nurse, but I guess impractical to do so?  
I would say that on calling the 111, initially it said something like this is not for what my issue was, but the surgery said to call them as all they could do was issue a prescription especially if Retention was suspected! Having spoken to the doctor surgery from home, the GP Prescription can be returned to pharmacy stock to save waste.

author: Waitingwaiting
title: Waiting far too long
body: Today marks day 416 as an urgent case for eating disorder services. No treatment is on the horizon either. According to April House I still and I quote have months and months left to wait. The wait has encouraged my eating disorder dramatically. With no opportunity insight their services have left me to become very suicidal.

author: juliethx66
title: The staff couldn't have been kinder
body: A big 'thank you' particularly to the receptionist and Physician's Assistant on duty in the  Emergency Department of Dr Gray's Hospital  the afternoon  of 25/04/2021 when I took  my 94  year old friend (who is routinely fitter and more active than many half the age) to the hospital with a suspected blood clot.   Despite all the additional pressures that the Covid-19 pandemic has created, the staff couldn't have been kinder and were extremely supportive to a patient who had  had no cause to visit a hospital in over15 years.

author: lepusdd47
title: I couldn't say anything bad about it
body:
GP referral this morning. GP told me to come to A&E. A&E directed me to EmSU. Only downside is it was very difficult to find. Could do with better signage.  
The girls have been lovely. The service has been very quick.  
Had a CT scan. I didn't have to wait long. A guy called Josh - He was lovely. Explained everything very well.  
Mo and Kevin the doctors included me in the information regarding my possible diagnosis.  
When I was admitted, I was in lots of pain but got painkillers straight away. I am diabetic. I am unable to eat and drink at present. They have been good at checking my sugars.  
I couldn't say anything bad about it.

readBy.name: Northern Health and Social Care Trust

author: listenbx97
title: Being mistreated
body:
I didn’t want to have to resort to posting on this site, but after so long of being mistreated I thought it was time to let everyone know. On a number of occasions we have had to deal with rude, unpleasant staff on reception. Don’t get me wrong there are staff who would go out of their way to help you, but at other times it's a different story. A family member has a rare condition, needing specialist medicine. This seems too much for them to handle as there always seems to be a problem with prescriptions, or they are causing us stress that isn’t needed! Time after time I have felt patronised by staff, so why is it ok for them to talk to us this way but as soon as you give it back it’s not allowed? I have also heard a member of staff speaking badly about me as a parent.Today I had confronted them about a prescription as my partner had called to change the mg of tablets and was told no they weren’t doing it, it wasn’t possible. I arrived at the practice to find out why this was as I couldn’t be bothered with the rudeness of staff over the phone, to which I was greeted by a hostile staff member who called my partner a liar and said they had actually passed it to the doctor to see if this could be done and to contact the hospital to send an email to them. So why tell my partner one thing and me the other? Why can it not be straightforward enough to tell us they would do what they can and offer to call the hospital. The way we are continually treated by staff is shocking, it’s a shame we can’t move doctors practice as this is the only one in our area.  
We as a family go through so much with caring responsibilities and don’t need this kind of attitude every single time we contact the doctors surgery. It puts you off even asking them for anything or even help. What kind of way is this to treat people who are already struggling?

readBy.name: North Lanarkshire Health & Social Care Partnership
Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2021)

author: Orla M
title: I feel very much in capable, caring hands
body:
I was diagnosed with PsA in December. My consultant, Dr. Wright and his registrar Dr. Anderson were very tentative, they listened to my concerns and fully assessed my symptoms, one of the great things about this diagnostic appointment was the ability for Dr. Wright to carry out ultrasounds of my joints then and there and explain what the presence of enthesitis meant.  
As I tried to get my head around a diagnosis of a lifelong condition, I worried about my care and starting treatment in the middle of a pandemic. However, all my fears have been allayed. Despite the impact of Covid, redeployments, virtual appointments etc. The rheumy team have been absolutely fantastic, the Rheumatology Helpline is such a lifeline and I’ve been completely supported over the last few months.  
I had a face to face appointment with my Rheumatology Specialist Nurse today, Anne, who is just fabulous and has offered me so much support since diagnosis. She is so knowledgeable about the disease, and listens with a caring, empathetic ear and offers sound, evidence based, constructive and reassuring advice in terms of what to do, what to expect and what the next plan of action is. She was supported today by staff nurse Una who really helped me feel at ease and supported. Even the ward clerk, as I awaited my appointment, was so friendly and welcoming.  
The shared care between my GP and the team has been very clear and executed without issue. I know that there is no magic wand that can be waved to send my PsA into remission and at the minute I’m so so sore, tired and fed up from it, but I don’t feel alone. I feel very much in capable, caring hands with a great consultant and specialist nurse and their team and I trust the careplan they have agreed with me as we try various medications to get the disease under control. I just wanted to take a moment to thank and acknowledge all the wonderful work they do.

readBy.name: Belfast Health and Social Care Trust

author: maytr95
title: One stop breast clinic
body: I had an appointment at the one step breast clinic at Wansbeck hospital after a 2 week wait. I accepted Wansbeck as it was the first available appointment offered and I was told by my GP that everything would be done today and I would get some results. After travelling for an hour and arriving in time for my appointment. I was shown in and met the consultant who examined me. After 2 or 3 minutes I was advised I would need a mammogram a CT scan and a biopsy and told me to make an appointment. I was informed that I could probably get one for that Thursday as there was no one in the radiology dept today to do anything!One stop meant no stop. I have a perfectly good hospital 10 minutes from my home but it is not a one-stop clinic. Needless to say I was extremely upset after spending 2 weeks worrying. I have an appointment on Tuesday at my local hospital with the x ray dept. Let’s hope they have staff to do the necessary test. I cannot believe they allowed me to travel for an hour to be told no more than my own GP had told me. I have no desire to go back to Wansbeck. I have no confidence in them so hopefully I will be able to get the tests and any treatment somewhere they at least tell you in advance if your journey will be wasted.

author: vegatd83
title: Absolutely excellent care
body:
I thought I'd leave some feedback about the district nurses.  
I'd never met any of the girls before but they have been excellent, absolutely excellent. Just 1st class care all round. Everything has been 100%, they have been very attentive, very knowledgeable.  
They explain everything they are doing as they do it, saying exactly what they are doing and why, and they say all the things like "this might hurt a wee bit" or whatever, makes the whole thing so much easier

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: TerrifiedTrekkie
title: Colposcopy following abnormal smear
body:
I had to attend a colposcopy following an abnormal smear test result, this was a very anxiety-inducing thing to happen as I had always had normal smear tests in the past (and have never missed an invite).  
The letters were somewhat confusing as I was told in one letter that I should arrive early and I could bring someone with me and yet a few pages on that was retracted and I was told I would have to attend alone and should not arrive too early as there is no where to wait. I was also told the site is well served by public transport - I looked into the options using the website suggested and my options were 2 bus journeys totalling nearly 2 hours of travel time and would arrive nearly an hour before my appointment or 15 minutes afterwards. The train was quicker however involved 3 changes and would have been expensive (approximately £17). I chose to drive as the car journey was only 25 minutes however on arrival I could not find a parking space (despite arriving 30 minutes early, planning to spend the extra time listening to the car radio to clam myself). I drove around the local area and found somewhere to park which was about a 10 minute walk away - that ate up all the extra time I had allowed myself to relax before the procedure.  
I arrived feeling like an anxious wreck however the staff were very welcoming and I was checked in smoothly. I was taken for my appointment not long after arriving and had a warm introduction to the Doctor who would be carrying out the procedure and her assistant. Everything was explained in plain English and I was given time to sort myself out.  
The procedure was uncomfortable and unpleasant however the edge was taken off this by the caring nature of the assistant who helped maintain a relaxed atmosphere throughout. At each stage I was told what to expect and had reassurance from the assistant. Overall I managed to stay relatively calm - surprising even myself.  
Afterwards I was given ample time to composes myself and had aftercare clearly explained - twice in fact as I didn't take it all in the first time and I had to ask them to repeat it which they did without judgement or comment.  
I am in some discomfort however I was told to expect this and I know the signs to look out for should an infection occur, I also feel reassured that should I need to call for help the Doctor will answer my queries.  
[Unhappy with 'Waiting time']  
[Very happy with 'Cleanliness']  
[Very happy with 'Seeing the whole me']  
[Happy with 'Introductions']

author: reticulumwd44
title: Telephones at GP
body: My GP practice has been getting work done on their phone system. Today I phoned to get results of a infection test. The phone went straight to prerecorded message telling me it was Tuesday and if I was phoning between 5. 30 and 6pm to phone another number. The number suggested was the same number as I had originally phoned and got the recorded message. I am an older person and I tried phoning the number also on the NI direct website and it simply rang out and went dead. I normally do not complain but today I was left feeling annoyed, upset, anxious after a nurse told me I needed to have an examination to rule other things out. The GP was supposed to have phoned me and I never received a call. There were no missed calls on my phone. The Nurse said she would leave a message for the GP to ring me before surgery was over and I got no call. I am asking for the GP practice to sort their phones so the public are not left in such a distressed state in future.

author: MistyMoo16
title: Appointment availability for results
body:
Tried to make an Appointment after my X-ray results were received, only to be told next Appointment would be June ( bearing in mind this happened at the end of April) I was then told I could have a telephone appointment on the 1st June. I would like to say this is very unprofessional and would like to see a new system in place, if u need to see a doctor you should be able to, and not wait weeks.  
Its not good enough in this day n age. Dont blame Covid.

readBy.name: Meadowgreen Health Centre & The Avenue Medical Practice

title: Mediocre understanding
body: I had a phone call with a dr not a name I recognised at the practice he didn’t really understand my issues and was very offhand asking what outcome i wanted.  He admitted he didn’t have experience of my issue and only did the basics as I’ve had before / the standard treatment tvsgvjvd had before and it’s not working and wasn’t offered anything else.  Very abrupt manner and difficult to understand I couldn’t understand what his name was.  Didn’t help my illness and BP at all which is being monitored

author: vyviren43
title: Poor care in GP office
body: After having a dip in my mental health, and being told by work to get signed off to get better, I went to see my GP about a sicknote. After a few weeks this needed to be renewed and the GP I saw was very unsympathetic, saying that I would need to be working again at some point, that feeling low isn't an excuse not to work, and very rudely and abruptly telling me that I should be medicated when I had said I'd like some details for a counselling service, because I didn't feel bad enough to be taking antidepressants and they're not something I want to use. I felt humiliated, and like I wasn't being respected.

title: Shambolic Admin
body: They have changed over to a new "online system" and cancelled the current one - only they haven't given anyone details on how to connect to the new one. It was hard enough getting registered for the old one  - which involved filling out a piece of paper manually!  They are very slow to answer the phone (wait times of over 40 mins) and awful at providing appointments. If you can get past all that and actually get an appointment - the doctors there are very nice and helpful.

title: Ward 9
body: Fantastic caring ward, all nurses and carers are helpful and caring putting patients first and foremost at all times. I felt at ease and kept in the full picture about my care, if I had to return I wouldn’t hesitate to go back on to ward 9.

title: Not a great practice at all.
body: I wouldn't recommend anyone with severe long term mental health conditions to go to this practice if their lives depended on it. I would have left a different response if the Team Leader was more responsive to requests for answers to certain questions, but I've been cold shouldered a number of times now. Worst practice in history. Bar None. Period. Should be ashamed of themselves.

readBy.name: Cumbria, Northumberland, Tyne and Wear NHS Foundation Trust

title: Part time GPS is the main reason of an appalling…
body: Latham House is the town's only practice and had always run within its means. This may have been long waits in the seating area waiting to be called in and at times somewhat frustrating or annoying but on the whole was acceptable knowing our Dr's are doing their best for their patients. You could see that the Dr's were sometimes run off their feet but we were always grateful to them for their time and care and the support staff were just that and woe betide if they put themselves between Dr and patient. It is very different now with the support staff becoming the gatekeepers and dare I say some are very indifferent to a patients concerns and rather trying to offer alternatives they feel justified  keeping the patients at bay by giving poor excuses that the Dr's are just unavailable. There isn't a particular shortage of Drs but many are now just part time. It is impossible to give a a quality of service to patients on part time hours. It just isn't possible. Our old style Dr's were worth their weight in gold, respected citizens of communities the nation over. GP Practices have slipped in their standards of care and Latham House is an example of what is going on nationwide.

title: Great staff.
body: We were seen quickly and safely. My baby was well looked after and the care was great. Thanks to all the staff.

title: Excellent customer service
body:
My family and I had both our vaccines at this practice 
Very easy to book an appointment, the staff were super helpful and polite 
They allowed us to book a time that was convenient for us
Have no hesitation in recommending this practice

author: vyviren43
title: Attitude on reception
body: When calling my GP about telephone appointments and reviews of tests etc, I was unaware of the time to call. When I last called about results the staff member I spoke to (who didn't give a name) barked that I should call back after 10am and hung up. I then called back because I had also wanted to book a telephone call with a GP, and the same person spoke to me. The tone was abrupt and rude, simply asking my name, D.O.B., Best number to call on, before saying that someone would call back and hanging up - no idea which doctor I'd speak to, no goodbye... I appreciate that Covid has an impact, but patients could be calling for any reason - and calls like that could deter patients from calling at all.

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2022)

title: Horrific experience!
body: Lack of care from the reception until the doctor. 3 hours waiting in agony even the 111 told me I will be seen within max 2 hours. Couldn't sit or walk properly. Was standing over 3 hours in waiting room. Nurse told me she will give something for the pain of my lower back. Didn't get anything. Left in agony with paracetamol from very unexperienced doctor without any comparison. Feeling worse then before I was seeking help.

title: Not a good experience
body:
I was registered for this surgery, the reception staff were nice.
I don't recommend GPS as they need more experience for individual cases

author: B181
title: Care received from the IHTT
body: Feeling low, unmotivated. Have really appreciated the team's input in trying to get me pass this stage.

title: Excellent service
body: Following major surgery, I was given an appointment at the Practice to have sutures removed (which I was not looking forward to!). The nurse who attended to me was compassionate and caring, and carried out the removal with considerable care and arranged to see me two days later to ensure that the healing process was continuing satisfactorily. Thank you so much.

title: Excellent Care
body: I would like to thank the Specialist Nurse at rheumatology Worcester Royal. She has worked tirelessly throughout the pandemic and the care she has given me is outstanding. Her knowledge and expertise has helped me greatly. She is always cheerful, dedicated and polite. I would like to say a very grateful thank you! I would also like to thank the nurse who stayed with me while I had the steroid injections. My support worker could not come in with me and the nurse was brilliant. Thank you again

author: limagn83
title: Helped so much
body: Mainali is one of the best MS nurses I have spoken to. Helped so much to get me on the right treatment and very understanding about MS. Thank you very much and would definitely recommend you.

author: karL21
title: My Mothers care in ward 4
body: My mother was nursed in ward 4 for some time. The staff, including Staff nurses Nicky and Kirsten were so compassionate. The care Mum received was exceptional. Our Borders general hospital calls their patients by their name and they are not a number

author: CardioACP
title: Outstanding compassionate care
body:
My 82 year old father was admitted to the Accident and Emergency Department with acute abdominal pain which was diagnosed as perforated bowel. I was helpfully updated by the consultant on my hasty journey across the country from Lincoln. With a very guarded prognosis, and rapid deterioration, the A&E team, surgeon, anaesthetist and ICU Dr respected him as an individual as we conveyed the greater-than-average aspirations of this octogenarian.  
He was transferred the intensive care unit following surgery and sadly died on his 9th day. During the time in ICU we were updated every day by the wonderfully kind Comms team. The ICU nursing staff went the extra mile to ensure they got to know about my father, playing his favourite jazz music and YouTube music of his granddaughter singing. They facilitated video calls (due to COVID restrictions) and anticipated our needs for kindness and information as much as they applied their shills to his care. They anticipated our spiritual needs and arranged for their wonderful chaplain to visit.  
Sadly, the complications of his illness were too great to overcome and my father died with me and my mother in attendance on the evening of 4th May. We were supported by the chaplain and his wonderful nurses during the most difficult goodbye.  
I am a healthcare professional, so accustomed to being on the other side of the care and conversations. The thoughtfulness and attention to detail was under my professional scrutiny, and it did not disappoint.  
Our whole family are so grateful to everyone involved in his pathway from the front door of A&E, to his final breaths on ICU.

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2021)
Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2022)

author: statusxt73
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: Covid vaccination
body: Had my 2nd vaccine in Foyle Arena. The service was very quick yet efficient. All chairs and equipment wiped down. I felt very safe. Well done NHS staff

readBy.name: Western Health and Social Care Trust

author: EmmaH
title: Great care in A&E
body: Both of my children were being seen at Lagan Valley Hospital A& E on 6 May. The staff treated myself with a great deal of compassion as if I was a patient too. I would like to thank Lee and Emily, the Doctors looking after us and also Scarlet and all of the other nurses for their care. Great team.

readBy.name: South Eastern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Benten14
title: First class from start to finish
body: Went for my second vacine today at Foyle Arena Londonderry and have to say the service was first class from start to finish. In and out in 30 minutes. Thank you to all the hard working staff.

readBy.name: Western Health and Social Care Trust

author: skyps99
title: Contraceptive Implant Exchange
body: As I arrived I was greeted by ‘the two Julies’ who were both so welcoming and lovely! All throughout the procedure I was well informed and I couldn’t have asked for any two lovelier nurses! They are both a credit to the team: )

author: Temple39
title: Covid vaccination centre
body: Very well organised facility, all staff were very friendly and very professional.

readBy.name: Western Health and Social Care Trust

author: GFL
title: Minor injuries treatment
body: One my children had injured his ankle playing volleyball. We decided to go to the minor injuries unit at South Tyrone Hospital. The service was excellent and the staff very helpful and welcoming. My child was assessed, x- rayed and treated all within 40 mins. This service is excellent, there should more units like it.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Good Looking
title: The nurses are fantastic
body: The Nurses in The High Dependancy Ward at The Royal Infirmary are FANTASTIC, I was in there a year past December, to tell you the truth, they all deserve a award, they could not do enough for me.

author: Em79
title: Friendly and pleasant
body:
I attended the vaccination centre at the Royal Victoria Hospital Belfast today. I just wanted to saw how great the staff were. A friendly greeting at the door was much appreciated.  
The nurses were so friendly and pleasant, particularly Sharon, Kathy and Valerie. Really excellent service, thank you all!

readBy.name: Belfast Health and Social Care Trust

author: authenticpd56
title: Lack of compassion
body: My father was on end of life care, every time I visited him I was met with confusion and a lack of compassion from staff, appearing to be unknowledgeable in team coordination and how to speak to someone with dementia.

readBy.name: Sheffield Teaching Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust
St. Andrews University ScotGEM Medical Students

author: msmith193
title: Birth of our daughter
body:
Just to say on behalf of my wife and myself that we had such a great experience during her admission for induction of labour at the ante-natal and labour wards.  
My wife was admitted on the Monday night to ante-natal and we were immediately put at ease. I was able to stay with her until she was settled and we knew what was happening. We were apprehensive that I wouldn’t be able to stay with her at admission but this was no problem what so ever.  
On the Tuesday her labour had started and was moved late morning to labour ward. They ensured my wife was able to get her epidural in a timely manner without delay. This meant she was more comfortable as the day went on. The midwife Hannah in labour ward was lovely. She kept us updated, well informed and gave us a few wee laughs along the way. They even made sure I was well looked after! Making me coffee and giving me lunch and dinner too. Nothing was too much trouble for us. They made us feel safe and gave us lots of good chat too!  
Unfortunately Hannah couldn’t stay with us as my wife’s labour progressed and we met the night shift team - the midwife Monica and student midwife Lisa. They were great too. Again like the rest of the staff they immediately made us feel at ease and were so down to earth.  
We were so impressed with the student midwife. She led the delivery and helped bring our lovely new baby girl into the world.  
After the birth, the amazing care continued. The tea and toast was great. They didn’t rush me away and allowed us to have a precious few hours together as a family.  
The midwives were a true credit to their profession. Thank you so much.

author: Elizabeth2003
title: My little boy cut his foot
body: We took him to Arbroath a& e and they were absolutely AMAZING with him he screamed the place down and they stayed so calm and talked him threw it all. They made me feel better too as it was so stressful. Couldn't of been in better hands. See you again tomorrow.

title: Excellent care at a difficult time
body:
I’d like to thank the staff at Linthorpe Surgery for the impressive level of care over the last 18 months or so

The COVID vaccination system has worked quickly and smoothly and I’ve found responses on eConsult to be efficient and effective. It must have been a very difficult operation to change the way they work quickly and organise vaccinations for so many.  Great work!

The staff who great patients into the building could adopt a slightly less aggressive tone of voice, but I’m sure they must find themselves in some stressful situations.

title: Well done and thank you
body: This must be the only place that has stayed open during the pandemic! Very pleased with my GP surgery and all the hard work they do and help they give. Within a day of submitting a request I had a call from my GP to check up on me.

title: Very attentive service
body: The GP spent some time going through the options to my medical issue and was very friendly and reassuring.

title: Cannot get through on the phone
body: I have been ringing this surgery for days,all day! Tried again this morning! We are told not to visit the surgery due to coronavirus. I just want my fit note!

title: Great experience
body: The lady that phoned me was understanding and kind, gave me a better outcome than I was expecting - I felt like I was really listened to.

title: Endoscopy  Dept
body: Fantastic staff from check in to check out, put me at ease, talked to me, reassured me, nothing was too much trouble, so grateful for their care and consideration, I have to return in 8 weeks for same procedure but am feeling very reassured and ok about it

title: Thank you
body: Like everyone else, I find the current situation so frustrating and long to be able to sit and consult face-to-face. But I am sure it is equally difficult for all of you at the practice, and especially for doctors diagnosing over the 'phone. Personally I find everyone pleasant and helpful once I do manage to get through. I left message online on Saturday and Receptionist called me back 8.30 Monday morning.Thank you all for that you are doing under trying circumstances,  Looking forward to a day when we can again meet freely and easily. Take care.

author: flutexz93
title: Implant removal
body: Was quite nervous about the procedure, but was totally reassured and made to feel comfortable. It was done before I new it. Thank you x

title: Great service
body: Taken by ambulance after a fall in the street, the service I received was first class. I was kept informed at all times, given a ct scan in rapid time, and the staff were very helpful. Discharged with crutches in under 3 hours.What a great NHS service, I cannot praise enough.

author: rhinoxr47
title: COVID Vaccine
body:
I received both of my vaccines in the South Lakes Centre, my second one today.
I felt it was very well organised and safe. Staff were helpful and pleasant and I’m glad I went and got the vaccine.
The process was very straightforward and the layout of the centre was excellent.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

title: Overall a good practice
body: We have been with the Spring Grove practice as a family now for c. 15 year and overall have had a very good experience. Yes we have had minor issues with clerical/admin staff in the past - however, recently (i.e. over the past couple of years) the quality of service from the reception team has greatly improved. With regards to the clinical team - i.e. doctors and nurses et al: we could ask for no better there support both prior to and during the Covid-19 pandemic has been excellent. So thank you to the Spring Grove Team.

title: Minor injuries, great service
body: Fell over in street, went to the unit and was treated almost immediately, great service, caring friendly staff and a credit to the NHS. Well done.

readBy.name: Kent Community Health NHS Foundation Trust

author: Mrs PB23
title: COVID Vaccine
body:
I have now had both vaccines at The Corn Exchange in Cupar. All staff were welcoming, professional and reassuring. I felt very safe and impressed with the set up following COVID guidelines.  
The Fife vaccine team deserve huge plaudits for setting up their programme in such difficult challenging times with huge pressure on timescales.

title: A complete waste of everyone’s time
body:
I was admitted due to possible post-surgical infection. The staff were the rudest staff I have ever come across in all my time being treated for a cardiac condition. I received absolutely no bed side manner, no communication. I understand resources are stretched, but I just cannot understand how you can be so rude. I wish it was an isolated case with an individual nurse but each one I dealt with was as uncaring as the next. The doctor who done the rounds spoke to me as if I was a 3 year old toddler that had no concept of my condition or medical terminology. The whole admission and stay was a complete and utter waste of everyone’s time and could have been resolved with a bit more communication at the time decisions were made.  
I’ve never been made feel more of a hindrance in a hospital environment than I did in that ward. Like I said, totally understand the job is horrific and the pressure is grand, but surely the profession requires an element of bedside manner. I had one HCA who was utterly wonderful and I just couldn’t understand why the rest were utterly dreadful. The porters, HCA’s & all doctors and nurses in A&E were absolutely wonderful (including a nurse who was so kind). Perhaps the professionalism in A&E set the bar too high.  
This has undoubtedly made me feel that I will refrain so much more from calling 111 when there may be an issue, if it means being treated like I am a massive inconvenience.

readBy.name: North Lanarkshire Health & Social Care Partnership

title: Best Practice
body: I have nothing but praise for the entire staff of Valley Road. Polite, friendly, caring and knowledgeable. I have never had an issue booking an appointment, receiving treatment or getting a referral, even during the pandemic. The best surgery I have ever been a patient with.

author: jupiterrw44
title: Outstanding service
body: My first coil appointment was unfortunately unsuccessful. However Dr Kundu went out of his way to make sure I got one fitted. The service was outstanding from Dr Kundu and the rest of the clinical team. The staff were warm, professional and respectful. I have full confidence in this service and I would go back again.

title: Great practice and Doctors.
body: I had a telephone appointment today for myself and my daughter. The doctor who assessed us, we have seen and spoke to a couple of times prior, and I must say I am always happy with the consultations. The level of advice given, treatment and efficiency is of good standard. I always feel comfortable and at ease. I have been with the practice about a year now, and I have had appointments with three of the Doctor's at the practice. I have not found to have had any problems. Thank you Quayside.

title: Great experience
body: After being rushed to a&e by two lovely paramedics, I was met with great doctors and nurses who made sure I was comfortable and tended to as soon as possible. I was scared to be in a resus room but the nurse made sure to reassure me every time she came into the room. They explained every step that they were taking and didn’t do anything without asking for my permission first, which I really appreciated.

readBy.name: London North West University Healthcare NHS Trust

title: Excellent service
body:
Minor Injuries Unit
Competent and friendly staff, no fuss or hassle to thoroughly asses your injuries and find the best solution. We got an immediate referral to the specialist needed for further examination and treatment. I can't thank this unit enough and they are doing an amazing job. Well Done! :)

readBy.name: Dorset HealthCare University NHS Foundation Trust

title: Good practice
body: Doctor was very informative and was able to create a comfortable atmosphere. There was also a skin specialist onsite, this was very helpful.

author: unhappy mama
title: Maternity Services
body:
Every aspect of myself and my sons care throught my pregnancy and afterwards was littered with failures and the impact this has had on our family has been vast.  
I discovered I was pregnant in June 2018, at about 8 weeks pregnant I had some spotting and attended EPAS where I was delighted I was expecting twins. At the time it was reccomend on my notes that I be scanned earlier than 12 weeks to monitor growth of my twins, this did not happen. Devastatingly at my 12 week scan ( done at 13 weeks) we were told that one of our babies had not made it. At this appointment I was ensured I would be contacted by a specialist nurse for blood testing as the normal tests would not work following the loss of a twin, however again this did not happen. I wrongly assumed that I would be offered extra scans following a loss but was told this was not done, resulting in us paying for private scans to offer us any reassurance that my remaining baby was ok. I never seen the same community midwife throughout my pregnancy, there was no consistency in my care.  
My stepdaughter has a rare genetic condition that my partner is a known carrier for and when I expressed concerns with regards to this at appointments this was wholly dismissed. When I enquired about the specialised test I was supposed to have, I was informed that "Its too late now". I suffered from hyperemesis throughout my pregnancy and was hospitalized several times for this due to dehydration. On one occasion towards the end of my pregnancy my bump was not measured due to lack of a tape measure resulting in my next appointment being informed that my baby had not grown in one month resulting in me being sent for an urgent scan the following day to be informed my baby was fine, and weighed 9lb.  
At no point was my birth plan discussed or completed my wishes were never considered. I was induced following an admission due to reduced movement at 6 days overdue. After 16 hours of labour my son had became stuck and I had a surgical procedure to deliver him. Due to retaining both placentas I bled excessively after this which left me very poorly. My son was thankfully born healthy and well which I am grateful for.  
On the maternity ward later that evening I was delighted to overhear a conversation between 2 care assistants complain about the noise earlier in the day from the induction suite, one of which was me and this same care assistant when I was attempting to breast feed my son barked at me that I "was doing it wrong" then left. The following day I was informed I required a blood transfusion that I refused as I just wanted home with my son due to the difficulties I had throughout.  
On my discharge I was told I would be referred to a physio as my son was 9lb 4, once again this has never materialised. My care in the community was much better with the exception of my sons health visitor visits. His first health visitor was fantastic but after she moved areas the visits stopped and my son has not been seen since he was 4 months old, he is now 2. This in itself is alarming, but I'm fortunate that he is thriving. All of this has resulted in physical problems that are starting to materialize for myself now. However the greatest impact my pregnancy and birth experience has had is on my family. Due to the lack of care, communication, understanding and negligence we have decided as a not to expand our family further. This has been devastating and difficult to come to terms with as the inaction of multiple others has impacted on my families life in a massive way.  
I do not wish my story to be used as a "learning experience" as it is clear that my issues were widespread and require more action than that. I have written this as I hope that after 2 years something that I am only just coming to terms with, finally someone hears my voice, and actually listens.

author: JMAC1
title: Home Care
body: Monklands Home Care Team came out to attend to my elderly mother. The Team were very friendly and supportive but more importantly understanding to our situation and sensitive to my mothers needs. Service was also prompt and efficient. My mother is a very frail and anxious person and was comforted a great deal by the team.

readBy.name: North Lanarkshire Health & Social Care Partnership

title: Good Customer Service
body:
They have a great Customer Seevice with prompt response to their 
Patients.
Clinic is well cleaned and staff is very helping.

title: Efficient given the pandemic
body:
My call was answered quickly and politely by the receptionist.
I was directed to the physiotherapist and this worked well.
Keep up the good work thank you

author: LynFa11
title: Thank you for my care
body:
I contacted nhs inform due to having abdo pain.  
The care I received from the call handler all the way through to the staff at surgical receiving at GRI was excellent and I can’t thank them all enough. I just wanted to pass on my gratitude.

title: Excellent mental health support service.
body: I have been so lucky to be registered at DMC as they have the foresight to have a dedicated mental health nurse, who has been completely invaluable in guiding me through severe anxiety and depression over the pandemic.  Without her considerable expertise and kind understanding and support I don't know how I would have survived this very difficult time.   Her service to the community is impeccable and has provided an intervention that was critical to my wellbeing and recovery and didn't waver over the pandemic.   All GPs should have such a service - congratulations and thank you DMC for having such a world class service.

title: Best practice in Bridgwater vB
body: Been with this practice when it was in Monmouth st,over fifty years would not go anywhere else.All the staff very helpful and pleasant.

title: Great practice
body: Good practice and very well trained staff. I had no issues in visiting the GP Practice. Although I did not have any major issues it was solved by the GP at the time of visit.

author: GPC2019
title: Excellent post natal care
body:
I recently gave birth in Lagan Valley Hospital. I just wanted to highlight the exceptional care we received there both antenatally and postnatally everyone has been amazing. However it was during labour that we had two wonderful midwives Joanne and Sharon who helped bring our beautiful baby boy into the world. Shortly after his birth there were some concerns from my husband and myself along with the midwives that our baby had Down’s syndrome. This was later confirmed a few days later. However how this was handled in Lagan Valley was done so with the utmost respect and empathy during a very anxious, shocking and uncertain time for us. The Sister Claire squeezes my hand and gave me a hug. No words were needed but I’ll never forget that act of kindness that told me everything would be ok.  
We had to be transferred to the Ulster neonatal unit. This was something I always wanted to avoid and knew this was a possibly when giving birth in Lagan Valley. However the staff at the Ulster maternity unit and neonatal unit again went above and beyond in terms of their support and guidance. We were there five days and again I was so impressed with the standard of care we received from everyone. From the nurse who sat with my husband which he cried to the midwife who sat and listened to my fears and anxiety in the small hours of the morning as well as all the Breastfeeding support and guidance.  
We left the Ulster with a much more positive outlook for the future. People don’t always take the time to celebrate the positive experiences they have - much more likely to jump in and complain. I just wanted to say thank you to the entire team of paediatricians; midwives, neonatal nurses and health care workers who went above and beyond their job roles during our stay.  
We have been home two weeks nearly and are just loving the new addition to our family and enjoying every second. Thank you from the bottom of our hearts.  
Our son’s mum and dad xox

readBy.name: South Eastern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Invisible service user
title: Bloods
body: No service provision on a weekend for blood taking or a late night. I work for a corpy that isn’t very friendly to its staff so getting time to go for bloods in the week is not possible. The service times for all the options is very narrow. Basically 8-5. I set off for work at 6: 30 and get back just before 7 during the week. So the service availability to me is none existent. Would it be possible to look at one site having a late opening or weekend opening? im sure there would be many like me who would use such a service.

readBy.name: York and Scarborough Teaching Hospital NHS Foundation Trust

author: Stressed teacher
title: Wonderful service with a human touch
body:
I got stuck in terrible traffic and was running late for my appointment. I called the surgery and the very lovely Nicky answered my call. She was so helpful and slotted me in for another appointment. Then, while waiting at the desk, Nicky came out from the back office, called my name and had booked me in! She then came over and checked on me as I must have looked stressed. She was so kind and lovely. On a terrible day, she made a difference. Then, the nurse I saw was also lovely. Her name was Ruth.  
I feel both ladies were outstanding and went above and beyond their duties to offer a wonderful service with a human caring touch! So, I wanted to say thank you and that it is very much appreciated!

author: Bainy
title: Recognising the role of the Doctor
body:
After a long day trying to liaise with primary care to support my sons symptoms we ended up at A&E. On arrival the nurse politely introduced herself and listened to what had brought us to the hospital. She reassured me as a mum I had done the right thing by bringing my son to the department. All the nurses showed professionalism by introducing themselves and complying with PPE, nothing was too much trouble.  
I would like to acknowledge a certain member within the department Dr Marc who I believe was a registrar. When Marc came to review my son he listened to not only my concerns but also my sons concerns and acted appropriately to offer reassurance. Marc demonstrated professionalism and had a natural ability through effective communication skills to make my son feel relaxed. Marc was attentive, supportive and most of all what a doctor should be caring and compassionate. I left the department knowing what I had to look out for and reassured should anything change to present at the department. Thank you and please continue to look after the kids the way you do. The emergency department has a fantastic team who are all dedicated and committed to succeed!  
Thank you and take care

author: Chanelcockburn28
title: The amazing staff members in ward 205
body:
I normally come into hospital at least 1/2 times a month for a period of 3-7 days until I recover, it’s been just over a year now that I have been unwell and in and out of hospital. I come to 205 quite a lot and out of all the wards  
I’ve been in at the royal infirmary the GI nurses in 205 are absolutely incredible there amazing with me, always have a smile on there faces they never moan or have an attitude they get on with there day and are absolutely amazing I couldn’t. thank them enough for looking after me with the highest of standard of care and compassion they deserve a medal for everything they do! I would like to thank Lisa, kay, Lauren, sue, elsie, carrie, Katie and there are so many more I have to apologise to the ones I can’t remember all there names but from the bottom of my heart THANKYOU LADIES  
you make the difference to my days when I’m feeling down and wanting to be home with my family yous cheer me up so much the care is remarkable once again I will never be able to thank yous enough. 10/10 I would give them keep being yous because yous are all incredible people and I’m so happy to have met yous.

title: Tonbridge Covid Vaccination Centre
body: I have now had both my Covid vaccinations at this centre and on both occasions the whole procedure was extremely professional, caring and pleasant.   Very impressed - thank you NHS

readBy.name: Kent Community Health NHS Foundation Trust

title: Terrible practice
body: I have used this practice since a young age, the last few years I've had nothing but issues everytime attending an appointment. The staff are not polite and very unhelpful. Struggling with mental health and calling for their help tp be told there is nothing they can do... I've had an issue being refused my medication but also been refused help towards it. I will NEVER visit this doctors surgery again.

title: Outstanding service
body: I have been a patient at Charnock Practice for over forty years. The current doctors, nurses and staff are the most caring that have ever worked there.  They have performed a brilliant job during this pandemic.  Definitely the best practise in Sheffield.  A deserved five-star review.

title: Ridiculous appointment system
body:
Managed to get an appointment over the phone back in feb. Still having problems to this day but can’t get an appointment because you have to ring at 8am to get one. When you ring at 8 the phone line is busy for I’d say over an hour then when you finally get through to reception there’s no appointments left. Not easy for parents with children to get ready for school and having to keep ringing the doctors, only
Option is to go to the walk in centre. No priority for carers either.

title: It is now unreachable - Do not register with this…
body: This used to be a great clinic. Since it has been taken over by the West London Group Practices it has become totally unreachable. It is impossible to talk to anyone in the clinic unless you give all your data to a private mobile application company. This clinic offers no services to people who cannot use/do not want to use mobile phone application due to privacy concerns. They keep you waiting on the line for up to 40 min and then when you reach number 1 in the line they hang up. Absolutely useless clinic.

title: Poor before Covid, poor now
body: Couldn’t do an Econsult on Friday, had to wait until Monday. Will not receive a call regarding my condition until Friday. So there will be a week between wanting to get a consult and actually getting one.

title: Disappointing
body: We've been with Walford Mill for the past 6 years, since moving into the area, & have always been delighted with the caring service. So whilst I appreciate covid has changed things, I was really disappointed to call here today to book a blood test, ahead of my regular cancer appointment as I have done for the past 2 years, to be told this service is no longer available.  I have been avoiding hospitals, due to shielding, but am now going to have to risk going into hospital for my blood test, before a phone appointment with oncologist, to save me the risk of going into hospital. Beggars belief!  Not impressed Walford Mill.
